sen.j: 奈良県御所市（ごせし）の地名。
sen.e: Gose is a city name for Gose City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: 御所号のこと。
sen.e: Gosho refers to the gosho-go.
Gosho refers to the gosho-go.

sen.j: 御所号とは天皇家及び将軍など貴人の住居及びその人の尊称として許された称号。
sen.e: The gosho-go is an honorific title to refer to the nobles such as the Imperial Family and shogun as well as their residences.
The gosho-go is an honorific title which refers to nobles such as the Imperial Family and shogun as well as their residences.
The gosho-go is an honorific title which refers to nobles such as the Imperial Family and shogun as well as their residences.

sen.j: よみがな：（ごしょ/ごしょごう）。
sen.e: It is read gosho or gosho-go.
It is read gosho or gosho-go.
It is read gosho or gosho-go.

sen.j: 本稿ではこれを記す。
sen.e: In this section, the gosho-go will be discussed.
In this section, the gosho-go will be discussed.
In this section, the gosho-go will be discussed.

sen.j: 柿の品種の一つ
sen.e: Gosho refers to a variety of persimmon.
Gosho refers to a variety of persimmon.
Gosho refers to a variety of persimmon.

sen.j: 御所（ごしょ）とは主に天皇家の住居または天皇のことを指す。
sen.e: The Gosho generally refers to residences of the Imperial Family or the Emperor himself.
The Gosho generally refers to residences of the Imperial Family or the Emperor himself.
The Gosho generally refers to residences of the Imperial Family or the Emperor himself.

sen.j: その他、太上天皇(太上法皇)の御所を院御所または仙洞御所といい、皇太后等の御所を女院御所、大宮御所という。
sen.e: Additionally, the Gosho for retired emperors (cloistered emperors) is called In Gosho or Sento Gosho, and the one for empress dowagers is Nyoin Gosho or Omiya Gosho.
Additionally, the Gosho for retired emperors (cloistered emperors) is called In Gosho or Sento Gosho, and the one for empress dowagers is Nyoin Gosho or Omiya Gosho.
Additionally, the Gosho for retired emperors (cloistered emperors) is called In Gosho or Sento Gosho, and the one for empress dowagers is Nyoin Gosho or Omiya Gosho.

sen.j: その他にも皇族、大臣、将軍の住居またはその人、その直系または傍系の子弟・子孫のことを指す場合もある。
sen.e: The Gosho may also refer to members of the Imperial Family, ministers, and shogun themselves as well as their residences and direct or collateral children and descendants.
The Gosho may also refer to members of the Imperial Family, ministers, and shogun themselves as well as their residences and direct or collateral children and descendants.
The Gosho may also refer to members of the Imperial Family, ministers, and shogun themselves as well as their residences and direct or collateral children and descendants.

sen.j: 特に大臣家以上の公卿の子弟に対して御室御所と敬称する習慣もあり、御所号は皇室のみならず、公家・武家の高位者にも広く用いられた。
sen.e: There was a custom to refer as Omuro Gosho to children of high nobles ranking higher than ministers, and thus the gosho-go was widely given not only to the Imperial Family but also high-ranking nobles and samurai families.

There was a custom to refer to children of high nobles ranking higher than ministers as Omuro Gosho, and thus the gosho-go was widely given not only to the Imperial Family but also high-ranking nobles and samurai families.

There was a custom to refer to children of high nobles ranking higher than ministers as Omuro Gosho, and thus the gosho-go was widely given not only to the Imperial Family but also to high-ranking nobles and samurai families.
sen.cmt: "but also high-ranking nobles"→"but also to high-ranking nobles"に変更しました。

sen.j: さらには、皇族・摂家の子弟が門跡となった寺院にも御所号が贈られることもあった。
sen.e: The gosho-go was even awarded to the temple at which the head priest was a son of the Imperial Family or the sekke (family of a regent or a chief advisor to the Emperor) at times.
At times, the gosho-go was even awarded to the temple at which the head priest was a son of the Imperial Family or the sekke (family of a regent or a chief advisor to the Emperor).
At times, the gosho-go was even awarded to the temple at which the head priest was a son of the Imperial Family or the sekke (family of a regent or a chief advisor to the Emperor).

sen.j: 将軍の居館の称としての御所
sen.e: Gosho to refer to shogun's residences
Gosho which refer to shogun's residences
Gosho which refer to shogun's residences

sen.j: 鎮守府将軍藤原秀衡の屋形を伽羅御所という。
sen.e: The residence for Shogun of the chinju-fu (local military office), FUJIWARA no Hidehira, was called Kyara no Gosho.
The residence for Shogun of the chinju-fu (local military office), FUJIWARA no Hidehira, was called Kyara no Gosho.
The residence for Shogun of the chinju-fu (local military office), FUJIWARA no Hidehira, was called Kyara no Gosho.

sen.j: 征夷大将軍源頼朝の屋形を大倉御所という。
sen.e: The residence for Sei Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo), MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, was referred to as Okura Gosho.
The residence for Sei Taishogun (Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo), MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, was referred to as Okura Gosho.
The residence for Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), MINAMOTO no Yoritomo, was referred to as Okura Gosho.
sen.cmt: seii としました。"(Barbarian Subduing Generalissimo)"→"(literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")"に変更しました。

sen.j: 足利将軍家の屋敷を室町御所または花の御所という。
sen.e: The residence for the Ashikaga Shogunate family was called Muromachi Gosho or Hana no Gosho.
The residence for the Ashikaga Shogunate family was called Muromachi Gosho or Hana no Gosho.
The residence for the Ashikaga Shogunate family was called Muromachi Gosho or Hana no Gosho.

sen.j: 福原京にあった平清盛の山荘を雪見御所という。
sen.e: The villa for TAIRA no Kiyomori in Fukuhara-kyo (imperial capital) was called Yukimi Gosho.
The villa for TAIRA no Kiyomori in Fukuhara-kyo (imperial capital) was called Yukimi Gosho.
The villa for TAIRA no Kiyomori in Fukuhara-kyo (imperial capital) was called Yukimi Gosho.

sen.j: 御所号
sen.e: Gosho-go
Gosho-go
Gosho-go

sen.j: 摂家や将軍家とその一門、公卿、寺社に許された御所の称号を御所号という。
sen.e: The gosho-go is an honorific title to be awarded to the sekke, shogunate families and clans, high nobles, temples and shrines.
The gosho-go is an honorific title awarded to the sekke, shogunate families and clans, high nobles, temples and shrines.
The gosho-go is an honorific title awarded to the sekke, shogunate families and clans, high nobles, temples and shrines.

sen.j: 御所号は主に朝廷や幕府がそれぞれ家柄や格式によって寺社・公家・大名家に許すものであり、尊称としては最高級に位する。
sen.e: The Imperial Court or the Shogunate mostly awarded the gosho-go to temples, shrines, nobles, daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) families according to their family lineages and social status, and the title is considered to be the most honorific.

The Imperial Court or the Shogunate mostly awarded the gosho-go to temples, shrines, nobles, daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) families according to their family lineages and social status, and the title is considered to be the most honorific.

The Imperial Court or the Shogunate mostly awarded the gosho-go to temples, shrines, nobles, daimyo (Japanese feudal lord) families according to their family lineages and social status, and the title is considered to be the most honorific.

sen.j: 朝廷が授与する御所号は、主に皇族や摂家の子女が門跡となった寺社に対して授与するものが主であり、その他、公卿もその家人より御所、或いは御所様（ごしょさま）、上様などと尊称されることが事実上許されていた。
sen.e: The Imperial Court mainly gave the gosho-go to the temples and shrines at which the head priest was a son or daughter of the Imperial Family or the sekke; moreover, high nobles were practically allowed to be referred to as Gosho, Gosho-sama, or Ue-sama by their families.

The Imperial Court mainly gave the gosho-go to the temples and shrines at which the head priest was a son or daughter of the Imperial Family or the sekke; moreover, high nobles were practically allowed to be referred to as Gosho, Gosho-sama, or Ue-sama by their families.

The Imperial Court mainly gave the gosho-go to the temples and shrines at which the head priest was a son or daughter of the Imperial Family or the sekke; moreover, high nobles were practically allowed to be referred to as Gosho, Gosho-sama, or Ue-sama by their families.

sen.j: 一方、武家政権においては室町幕府及び江戸幕府が一門または臣下のうち、御所号に匹敵する格式を有する家にこれを許した。
sen.e: On the other hand, the samurai governments of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and the Edo bakufu awarded the gosho-go to the family with social status eligible for the gosho-go among the shogunate clans and retainers.

On the other hand, the samurai governments of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and the Edo bakufu awarded the gosho-go to families having eligible social status for the gosho-go among the shogunate clans and retainers.

On the other hand, the samurai governments of the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) and the Edo bakufu awarded the gosho-go to families having eligible social status for the gosho-go among the shogunate clans and retainers.

sen.j: 室町時代、主に足利将軍家の当主及び連枝、鎌倉公方家の一門、或いは鎮守府将軍として南朝方の有力大名であった北畠氏とその一門が御所号を称した。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, the head and his siblings of the Ashikaga Shogunate family, the clan of the Kamakura Kubo (Governor-General of the Kamakura Government) family, and the powerful daimyo and shogun of the chinju-fu, the Kitabatake clan on the side of the nancho (Yoshino Imperial court), and its descendants were all entitled to the gosho-go.

In the Muromachi period, the head and his siblings of the Ashikaga Shogunate family, the clan of the Kamakura Kubo (Governor-General of the Kamakura Government) family, and the powerful daimyo and shogun of the chinju-fu, the Kitabatake clan on the side of the nancho (Yoshino Imperial court), and its descendants were all entitled to the gosho-go.

In the Muromachi period, the head and his siblings of the Ashikaga Shogunate family, the clan of the Kamakura Kubo (Governor-General of the Kamakura Government) family, and the Kitabatake clan who was a powerful daimyo on the side of the Nancho (Southern Court, or Yoshino Imperial court) who acted as the shogun of the chinju-fu, and its descendants were all entitled to the gosho-go.
sen.cmt: Nancho にSouthern Court と追加しました。北畠氏の説明を一部修正しました。

sen.j: 江戸時代には鎌倉公方家の流れを汲む喜連川氏が御所号を免許された。
sen.e: In the Edo period, the Kitsuregawa clan, descendants of the Kamakura Kubo family, was awarded the gosho-go.
In the Edo period, the Kitsuregawa clan, descendants of the Kamakura Kubo family, was awarded the gosho-go.
In the Edo period, the Kitsuregawa clan, descendants of the Kamakura Kubo family, was awarded the gosho-go.

sen.j: 特に京都室町における足利将軍家の邸宅を花の御所といい、将軍家当主も「公方様」ないし「御所様」と称された。
sen.e: The residence of the Ashikaga Shogunate family in Muromachi, Kyoto, in particular, was referred to as Hana no Gosho, and the head of the family himself was also called 'Kubo-sama' or 'Gosho-sama.'
The residence of the Ashikaga Shogunate family in Muromachi, Kyoto, in particular, was referred to as Hana no Gosho, and the head of the family himself was also called 'Kubo-sama' or 'Gosho-sama.'
The residence of the Ashikaga Shogunate family in Muromachi, Kyoto, in particular, was referred to as Hana no Gosho, and the head of the family himself was also called 'Kubo-sama' or 'Gosho-sama.'

sen.j: 特に、15代将軍足利義昭については、武家御所と称され、またかつての庇護者 織田信長と対立してよりは悪しき御所とも称された。
sen.e: Furthermore, the fifteenth Shogun, Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, was referred to as Buke Gosho (Samurai Gosho), but was also called Ashiki Gosho (Evil Gosho) after he was opposed to his ex-mentor, Nobunaga ODA.
Furthermore, the fifteenth Shogun, Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, was referred to as Buke Gosho (Samurai Gosho), but was also called Ashiki Gosho (Evil Gosho) after he was opposed to his ex-mentor, Nobunaga ODA.
Furthermore, the fifteenth Shogun, Yoshiaki ASHIKAGA, was referred to as Buke Gosho (Samurai Gosho), but was also called Ashiki Gosho (Evil Gosho) after he was opposed to his ex-mentor, Nobunaga ODA.

sen.j: 摂家の支流、一条兼家の屋形、または一条兼家をはじめとした土佐一条氏歴代当主の尊号を中村御所という。
sen.e: The honorific title for the branch families of the sekke, the residence of Kaneie ICHIJO, and the past heads of the Tosa-Ichijo clan including Kaneie ICHIJO was Nakamura Gosho.
The honorific title for the branch families of the sekke, the residence of Kaneie ICHIJO, and the past heads of the Tosa-Ichijo clan including Kaneie ICHIJO was Nakamura Gosho.
The honorific title for the branch families of the sekke, the residence of Kaneie ICHIJO, and the past heads of the Tosa-Ichijo clan including Kaneie ICHIJO was Nakamura Gosho.

sen.j: 一条兼定の嫡男 一条内政は大津御所と称され、土佐一条家最後の当主 一条政親は、久礼田御所と称された。
sen.e: The eldest son and heir of Kanesada ICHIJO, Tadamasa ICHIJO was referred to as Otsu Gosho, and the last head of the Tosa-Ichijo family, Masachika ICHIJO was called Kureda Gosho.
The eldest son and heir of Kanesada ICHIJO, Tadamasa ICHIJO was referred to as Otsu Gosho, and the last head of the Tosa-Ichijo family, Masachika ICHIJO was called Kureda Gosho.
The eldest son and heir of Kanesada ICHIJO, Tadamasa ICHIJO was referred to as Otsu Gosho, and the last head of the Tosa-Ichijo family, Masachika ICHIJO was called Kureda Gosho.

sen.j: 北畠顕成の子北畠顕忠が「北畠少弐」を名乗り、奥州岩手郡に下向して滴石御所と名乗った（御所ダムの由来）。
sen.e: The son of Akinari KITABATAKE, Akitada KITABATAKE, named himself 'Shoni KITABATAKE', and then called himself Shizukuishi Gosho when he went down into Iwate-gun in Oshu Province (the origin of Gosho Dam).

The son of Akinari KITABATAKE, Akitada KITABATAKE, named himself 'Shoni KITABATAKE', and then called himself Shizukuishi Gosho when he went down into Iwate-gun in Oshu Province (the origin of Gosho Dam).

The son of Akinari KITABATAKE, Akitada KITABATAKE, named himself 'Shoni KITABATAKE,' and then called himself Shizukuishi Gosho when he went down into Iwate-gun in Oshu Province (the origin of Gosho Dam).
sen.cmt: 括弧の位置を変更しました。

sen.j: 足利将軍家の一門、斯波詮真のことを斯波御所という。
sen.e: A member of the Ashikaga Shogunate family, Akizane SHIBA was referred to as Shiba Gosho.
A member of the Ashikaga Shogunate family, Akizane SHIBA was referred to as Shiba Gosho.
A member of the Ashikaga Shogunate family, Akizane SHIBA was referred to as Shiba Gosho.

sen.j: また、高水寺斯波氏の庶子 雫石詮貞を雫石御所、 猪去詮義を猪去御所といった。
sen.e: Akisada SHIZUKUISHI, an illegitimate child of the Kosuiji-Shiba clan was called Shizukuishi Gosho while Akiyoshi ISARI was referred to as Isari Gosho.
Akisada SHIZUKUISHI, an illegitimate child of the Kosuiji-Shiba clan was called Shizukuishi Gosho while Akiyoshi ISARI was referred to as Isari Gosho.
Akisada SHIZUKUISHI, an illegitimate child of the Kosuiji-Shiba clan was called Shizukuishi Gosho while Akiyoshi ISARI was referred to as Isari Gosho.

sen.j: 足利一門の吉良氏は三河国と武蔵国に勢力を置いたが、武蔵の吉良氏は世田谷御所、吉良御所と称された。
sen.e: The Kira clan, a Ashikaga clan, gained influence over Mikawa Province and Musashi Province, and the Kira clan in Musashi Province was referred to as Setagaya Gosho or Kira Gosho.
The Kira clan, a Ashikaga clan, gained influence over Mikawa Province and Musashi Province, and the Kira clan in Musashi Province was referred to as Setagaya Gosho or Kira Gosho.

sen.cmt: an Ashikaga clan としました。

sen.j: また、その支流である勝見氏は勝見御所といった。
sen.e: Its branch clan, the Katsumi clan, was called Katsumi Gosho.
Its branch clan, the Katsumi clan, was called Katsumi Gosho.
Its branch clan, the Katsumi clan, was called Katsumi Gosho.

sen.j: 室町将軍家の足利義満の子足利義嗣の子孫は越前に下り鞍谷氏となり、鞍谷御所と称された。
sen.e: The descendants of Yoshitsugu ASHIKAGA, a son of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA of the Shogunate family in the Muromachi period, went down into Echizen Province, became the Kuratani clan, and were referred to as Kuratani Gosho.

The descendants of Yoshitsugu ASHIKAGA, a son of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA of the Shogunate family in the Muromachi period, went down into Echizen Province, became the Kuratani clan, and were referred to as Kuratani Gosho.

The descendants of Yoshitsugu ASHIKAGA, a son of Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA of the Shogunate family in the Muromachi period, went down into Echizen Province, became the Kuratani clan, and were referred to as Kuratani Gosho.

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)の公卿、北畠顕家は船越御所と称され、子孫一門は戸木御所、袰綿御所と称された。
sen.e: Akiie KITABATAKE, a high noble in the Nanbokucho period, was referred to as Funakoshi Gosho, and his descendants were called Heki Gosho or Horowata Gosho.
Akiie KITABATAKE, a high noble in the Nanbokucho period, was referred to as Funakoshi Gosho, and his descendants were called Heki Gosho or Horowata Gosho.
Akiie KITABATAKE, a high noble in the period of the Northern and Southern Courts (Japan), was referred to as Funakoshi Gosho, and his descendants were called Heki Gosho or Horowata Gosho.
sen.cmt: 南北朝の補足をしました。"the Nanbokucho period (the period of the Northern and Southern Courts)"→"the period of the Northern and Southern Courts"に変更しました。

sen.j: また、北畠顕家の後裔である浪岡北畠氏は浪岡御所、その一族を川原御所という。
sen.e: The Namioka-Kitabatake clan, descendants of Akiie KITABATAKE, was referred to as Namioka Gosho, and its descendants were called Kawahara Gosho.
The Namioka-Kitabatake clan, descendants of Akiie KITABATAKE, was referred to as Namioka Gosho, and its descendants were called Kawahara Gosho.
The Namioka-Kitabatake clan, descendants of Akiie KITABATAKE, was referred to as Namioka Gosho, and its descendants were called Kawahara Gosho.

sen.j: 伊勢の公家大名、北畠氏は多芸御所または霧山御所という。
sen.e: The Kitabatake clan, noble daimyo in Ise Province, was called Tagi Gosho or Kiriyama Gosho.
The Kitabatake clan, noble daimyo in Ise Province, was called Tagi Gosho or Kiriyama Gosho.
The Kitabatake clan, noble daimyo in Ise Province, was called Tagi Gosho or Kiriyama Gosho.

sen.j: その一族の木造氏は木造御所、大河内氏は大河内御所、坂内氏は坂内御所、波瀬氏は波瀬御所、藤方氏は藤方御所、田丸氏は田丸御所といった。
sen.e: The Kozukuri clan, descendants of the Kitabatake clan, was referred to as Kozukuri Gosho; the Okochi clan Okochi Gosho; the Sakanai clan Sakanai Gosho; the Haze clan Haze Gosho; the Fujikata clan Fujikata Gosho; and Tamaru clan Tamaru Gosho.

The Kozukuri clan, descendants of the Kitabatake clan, was referred to as Kozukuri Gosho; the Okochi clan Okochi Gosho; the Sakanai clan Sakanai Gosho; the Haze clan Haze Gosho; the Fujikata clan Fujikata Gosho; and Tamaru clan Tamaru Gosho.

The Kozukuri clan, descendants of the Kitabatake clan, was referred to as Kozukuri Gosho; the Okochi clan Okochi Gosho; the Sakanai clan Sakanai Gosho; the Haze clan Haze Gosho; the Fujikata clan Fujikata Gosho; and Tamaru clan Tamaru Gosho.

sen.j: なお、歴史的な表現の方法として、親王または前職の征夷大将軍の尊称として大御所が使われた。
sen.e: As a form of historical expression, moreover, the honorific title, Ogosho (literally Big Gosho), was awarded to Imperial princes and cloistered Sei Taishogun.
sen.cmt: 「歴史的な表現の方法として」の文脈内での意味がよく分かりませんので、不自然ですが直訳しました。
sen.e: As a form of historical expression, moreover, the honorific title, Ogosho (literally Big Gosho), was awarded to Imperial princes and cloistered Sei Taishogun.
As a form of historical expression, moreover, the honorific title, Ogosho (literally Big Gosho), was awarded to Imperial princes and cloistered Seii Taishogun.

sen.j: なお、室町時代においては将軍、鎌倉公方及び足利一門、さらには北畠氏などが御所を称することができたが、江戸時代に鎌倉公方家の末裔である足利国朝が江戸幕府に帰参する折、御所号を許されている。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, shogun, the Kamakura Kubo family, Ashikaga clans, and the Kitsuregawa clan, for example, were entitled to the Gosho, and in the Edo period, Kunitomo ASHIKAGA, a descendant of the Kamakura Kubo family, was awarded the gosho-go when he returned to the Edo bakufu.

In the Muromachi period, shogun, the Kamakura Kubo family, Ashikaga clans, and the Kitsuregawa clan, for example, were entitled to the Gosho, and in the Edo period, Kunitomo ASHIKAGA, a descendant of the Kamakura Kubo family, was awarded the gosho-go when he returned to the Edo bakufu.

In the Muromachi period, shogun, the Kamakura Kubo family, Ashikaga clans, and the Kitabatake clan, for example, were entitled to the Gosho, and in the Edo period, Kunitomo ASHIKAGA, a descendant of the Kamakura Kubo family, was awarded the gosho-go when he returned to the Edo bakufu.

sen.j: この御所号に次ぐ敬称が屋形である。
sen.e: The second highest honorific title after the gosho-go is the Yakata.
The second highest honorific title after the gosho-go is the Yakata.
The second highest honorific title after the gosho-go is the Yakata.

sen.j: 東京
sen.e: Tokyo
Tokyo
Tokyo

sen.j: 皇居の御所（今上天皇、皇后）
sen.e: Kokyo (Imperial Palace) no Gosho (for the present Emperor and Empress)
Kokyo (Imperial Palace) no Gosho (for the present Emperor and Empress)
Kokyo (Imperial Palace) no Gosho (for the present Emperor and Empress)

sen.j: 吹上大宮御所（昭和天皇時代の御所で、その後、香淳皇后の大宮御所として利用されていた）
sen.e: Fukiage Omiya Gosho (the palace was originally the Gosho for the Emperor Showa, and was later used as Omiya Gosho, or Gosho for empresses, for Empress Kojun.)

sen.j: 京都

sen.j: 京都御所（天皇の在所を示す高御座が安置されている）
sen.e: Kyoto Gosho (the takamikura, or the Imperial throne to show the official residence of the emperor, is enshrined.)

sen.j: 京都大宮御所 女院御所（皇太后の御所として造営されたが、現在は天皇・皇后および皇族が京都へ帰洛した際に宿泊する）
sen.e: Kyoto Omiya Gosho (the Nyoin Gosho was originally built for the empress dowager, but is currently stayed by the Emperor, the Empress, and the Imperial Family when they visit Kyoto.)

sen.cmt: 女院御所 を括弧の外に出しました。

sen.j: 旧嘉陽宮邸跡 嘉陽宮家は上記とは別の女院御所旧地に設立された、築地は撤去された
sen.e: Kyu Kayanomiya Tei Ato, or Former Kayanomiya Family Residence Site (the Kayanomiya Residence was built on the site of the Nyoin Gosho different from the Nyoin Gosho above, and the residence was later demolished.)

sen.j: 仙洞御所（上皇の御所として造営されたが、焼失して現在は庭園と茶室のみ。）
sen.e: Sento Gosho (the Gosho was originally built for the retired emperor, but it was burned down, and its garden and tea room only remain today.)
Sento Gosho (the Gosho was originally built for the retired emperor, but it was burned down, and its garden and tea room only remain today.)
Sento Gosho (the Gosho was originally built for the retired emperors, but it was burned down, and its garden and tea room only remain today.)
sen.cmt: emperors と複数にしました。
